cons: 1. Hard to maintain work/life balance 2. Fundraising is difficult

pros: Autonomy, flexability, rewarding, great health benefits, fun!

review_title: Best work experience of my life!
job_title: Staff Associate in New York, NY
pros: My work at Young Life was unlike anything I've ever done before. It was tons of fun, allowed me to lean into my strengths, and challenged me in areas I could grow!
cons: You have to be good at managing your time, and keeping boundaries in order to have longevity.

pros: I loved working here so much
cons: No cons, great work environment

pros: YL covers all health insurance payments (aka nothing comes from your paycheck) - which once you're married + have kids is a $5K + savings. And on top of that, the health insurance plan is top-notch.
cons: *Leadership at Senior level is often not in touch with realities of what staff face day-to-day *Not great opportunities to continue growing on staff beyond serving as an Area Director

job_title: Hiring Assistant in Los Angeles, CA
pros: My co-workers and leadership team are incredibly caring. They have a deep sense of care for youth and desire to see impact made.
cons: Helpful to know the culture of YL prior to taking this role. The systems, language, and culture of how the people operate is a must.

job_title: Staff Associate Leadership Development Associate in Grand Rapids, MI
pros: Flexible hours and the benefits are amazing.
cons: If you truly want grow in Christ, you will eventually out grow young life. They don't get deep

review_title: Great mission, not so great salary
pros: Missional, Fun, intentional, deep roots, loving, great benefits
cons: Low pay, scared to change, small teams, not much room for growth

review_title: Can't Believe I Get Paid To Work Here
pros: -A lot of benefits: flexible hours, a lot of staff training, fun easy-going environment -Great salary (church fully funded it) -Family friendly
cons: -Ecumenical -Seeker-sensitive -Kids look more forward to camp, fellowship, and fun activities within this para-church mores than building a deep relationship with Christ in Bible reading, prayer, and church attendance

pros: Lifestyle/passion job, empowering others and being empowered, change the lives of young people
cons: Many evenings, difficult to "turn off"

pros: About all the right things
cons: Change is slow and hard. Big organization

pros: Calling filled job, great co-workers, flexibility
cons: On your own many times, volunteer dependent, fundraising

pros: rewarding and overall good place to be
cons: hard work that is not typical hours, ministry work

job_title: Associate Area Director in Lexington-Fayette, KY

cons: Low pay to some other ministry jobs

review_title: You have to be called and love it

cons: Low salary, hard to support a family

pros: • flexible hours • build relationships with high schoolers & help them grow • great coworkers
cons: • no structure • weird hours

pros: I like working here a lot
cons: Working here is a lot of fun

review_title: Great at community level; rough at national level
job_title: Associate Area Director in Portland, OR
pros: Great resources, a lot of great people, autonomy to lead in your community how you see fit
cons: National isn't actually willing to make any big shifts in policy or programming

pros:
- You get to work with kids
- YL has a weird amount of money so you get to do trips and staff outings that costs $$$$. Eg. I was flown to another country for some bs anniversary
cons:
- Racist, sexist and homophobic. As a bipoc female on staff, my supervisor treated me like a maid.
- You tell kids Jesus loves them but your trainer reminds you that it is with conditions
- YL is white. Very very white. Their clubs are white, majority of their management, and non white kids get slowly pushed out.
- Classist and transactional: if you’re not making relationships that can give you something your supervisor and trainer discourage it
- You fundraise half-all of your salary and it ruins your mental health and relationships. Not only that, the optics of YL and how they manage their funds made me seriously uncomfortable.
- No work/life balance. My trainer even told us that the hours we weren’t officially working we should be giving to YL voluntarily.
- Toxic environment; example: I was 15 minutes late to a meeting and got a call from my trainer during my off hours and got yelled at for an hour

pros: - You had the ability to determine your weekly schedule. - Amazing medical benefits. - Incredibly rewarding job. - Being able to mentor students.
cons: - There are some weeks when you are working very long hours.

pros: It was a wonderful experience
cons: Should look for more growth areas

review_title: Great Environment for Those Well Suited
pros: This really is a relational organization. For the most part, supervisors and peers are genuinely invested in each other’s success.
cons: Young Life does not allow members of the queer community to be volunteers or staff. They are protected by their status as a religious nonprofit.

job_title: Administrative Assistant II in Seattle, WA
pros: Meaningful mission Very relational team
cons: Do a lot of work totally on your own

review_title: flexible, event heavy, great community of people

cons: not much room for growth, low pay that does not keep up with inflation

pros: Flexibility Travel Work from home
cons: Raise your salary by yourself without help (I was hired by LAC)

cons: Long hours, mentally draining, a lot of time away from home

pros: My career development was taken seriously. Compensated fairly. Great people.
cons: There were very few cons.

review_title: A Job that challenges you to grow.

cons: Nothing is a con. Good environment

review_title: Great mission currently under very poor leadership

cons: It is still very much a good 'ol boys club. It is hard as a woman to feel respected, invested in or promoted. Very little consistency in job posting vs. appointments. Certain positions are not even posted and favorite individuals (usually white men) are placed into those positions without a process. Other positions "have to be posted" and fought for.

pros: The people at Young Life care about each other and have a passion for helping teenagers. The environment is fun and flexible. It is a job that offers great reward in serving others and knowing you are making a difference.
cons: Pay is not at market level for most positions. Hours are varied and can include early mornings and late nights.

pros: It definitely is a family.
cons: The pay could be a little better.

pros: Great mission and meaningful work.
cons: Not everyone on the team worked equally hard. Part time employees were often left out of trainings and retreats.

pros: Great flexibility and freedom. Best benefits I've ever seen. Lovely community and fellowship between other field staff.
cons:
As with many massive organizations, the higher ups are quite disconnected from the people doing the fieldwork. As such, policy change is slow and difficult. This is a "mission-oriented" organization, but much of the power and influence comes from large donors with specific and rigid agendas (moral majority).
Fundraising model makes it quite difficult from people of low socioeconomic background to actually last with a sustainable salary.

pros: Nice people, fun activities, working for a great cause, flexible hours (but really you're working any of the 24 hours, not a 9-5)
cons:
To be honest, it was hard to come up with a list of pros due to my experience. 
Pay is extremely low for the amount of stress (and you don't expect a lot working in the non-profit world). There's a lack of solid structure and accountability when it came to financials. Why have the area administrator approve the AD's purchases? It's backwards to have the employee approve their boss's purchases. 

We had major issues in my area that were eventually taken care of, but the main response I kept getting from Colorado was,"We'll pray on this." Very slow to actually take action. It reminded me of the joke about the guy on his roof during a flood, he ended up drowning and by the time he got to Heaven he said to God,"I was waiting for you to provide!" And God said,"I sent you a warning, a boat, AND a helicopter!"

job_title: Staff Associate II in Nashville, TN
pros: Serving the community & loving the city
cons: Micromanaging, miscommunication, lots of training and travel

job_title: Regional Director in San Francisco, CA
pros: Change the world one person at a time.
cons: If you're looking for high salary, you're looking in the wrong place/

pros: Treats employees well, with great benefit programs. Very relational staff.
cons: Pretty low pay for a demanding job, but as expected in ministry role.

pros: Very nice and the people here are amazing
cons: I can't think one Cons about this organization

pros: Health benefits are paid for and really good.
cons: You must fundraise all of your money.

pros: Flexible hours, kind people, great environment, good pay, great cause to work for, easy to fall in love with the job because of the AMAZING PEOPLE and their heart for God.
cons: lacking in structure, behind the times in technology

review_title: Love the mission but not the direction YL corp is headed
job_title: Area Director in Colorado Springs, CO
pros: Excellent mission and some of the most amazing people around work here... especially in the local areas.
cons: The Development Dept is weak and the mission has gotten too big to be funded properly... they have committed to raise a ton of money for the corporate parts of YL but not for the field staff and in my opinion is destained to fail.  We are raising too much money for camps and it's killing the local areas.  The development department has gotten too big and they are there for themselves -- not the field.  I saw a photo on fb and there were over 100 fundraisers at their retreat.  In the mean time, my area continued to loose donors to the corporate office.  Where's the help for the local staff?  While I don't like development and the direction they are headed, the mission is strong.  People out in the field doing YL everyday are doing amazing work.   My problem is with the corporate office that has grown too big!

pros: Great rewards and great property staff
cons: Physically might not be for everyone due to the work

review_title: You don’t want to know how the sausage is made
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Colorado Springs, CO
pros: Great camp locations and great benefits (especially for a non-profit). Getting to see kids "birthed" each week was an amazing experience. Worked with some very creative people.
cons: Ever heard the expression “You don’t want to know how the sausage is made”? Stay on the volunteer side of YL and you’ll keep your idealism. You’ll notice that very few of the reviews on this site related to the camping side of YL are positive. I worked full-time at more than one property and saw way too many unethical and self-serving financial decisions by managers as well as by field staff. It was an amazing place to be but when over 80% of my time & energy was spent dealing with “politics” and placating egos rather than taking care of guests/campers, I knew it was time to go.

pros: Working with a team of people committed to investing in our younger generations was some of the most rewarding work I've done. There were so many relationships built at a bunch of different levels: locally, regionally, nationally, even internationally. The potential for networking and creating support systems are amazing and broaden a community's capacity to change for the better.
cons: The donor fundraising model seems outdated and also struggles to work in a non-profit saturated society (the United States that is). Most, if not all staff positions requires the individual staff member to fundraise their own salary. This is neither sustainable nor viable - again, we've hit a societal saturation point in asking people for money.

review_title: Helping teens know what it means to follow Christ for life!!
pros: This was truly the most fascinating, most difficult, most inspiring, most worthy employment experience of my life to date. There is little in this world that is more important than working with the generation that is coming in behind us. Teens have a right to know about Jesus and how much He loves all of us!
cons: The downsides would be minimal from my perspective. The position of Area Director held significant flexibility and autonomy which is good for many and yet very hard for others. Being a self-starter and the fundraiser for expenses and for your own salary is challenging at times.

pros: Flexible work schedule, flexible time off,  excellent training
cons: HR is abysmal at applying due process  to the transitions of its employees (firing, resignation, etc). I would not be surprised if YL is served one day with a wrongful termination lawsuit. Great mission and heart overall in the organization, terrible follow-through and adherence to HR standards that are common practice in any major company.

job_title: College Area Director in San Diego, CA
pros: Pursue your passions while you are young, available, and energetic. Network with many different groups of people within your community, from students to financial professionals. People matter, relationship first kind of organization. Flexibility of schedule, good pay for the type of work, and you get to participate in a larger vision.
cons: The support the organization gives you is almost null. The typical answer when you run into management, finance, or logistical problems is go and fix it yourself, without much training on how to do it.

pros: The community has been the best part. Caring and loving environment while excelling in reaching a world of Kids! Honestly I have had flexibility in implementing different methods not from not having club (youth service) to having just basketball and open mic to having club with longer message times. Has decent benefits 401k options, Insurance, Gym, etc... This helps with trying to care for a full family yet remain in ministry.
cons: Downside is simply just lower then average pay. Teachers in our local school are always on strike and they get paid poorly but I struggle with having smaller pay then first year teachers.

pros: I love volunteering for younglife. You meet the best people and the mission is easy to stand behind as a Christian. The environment is great and it can actually be extremely  fun to hang out with high school kids.
cons: Sometimes there is a lack of structure because of the lack of people that younglife can afford to have on staff. But it kind of keeps things interesting because you have to be on your toes to figure out situations.

pros: I've been with Young Life over 16 years, now, and volunteered with them for 12 years prior to that. They really care about kids, leaders and adults who support the ministry. The work environment is refreshingly professional. I have worked for a Fortune 500 energy company, a national charity organization, and a handful of mom and pop companies. Young Life has been my favorite place to work, by far. They really care for their employees, and their health benefits are as good as they get.
cons: It's hard to think of any cons. I suppose sometimes working on a tighter budget could be one of them. But, that just forces you to be more creative.

pros: Lots of interaction with very friendly people.  You will make more friends in this job than you will anywhere and you will meet people from all over the world.  They also have incredible benefits
cons: long hours, upper management is completely out of touch with rest of the mission, low pay.  Prepare to have your work life and home life merge

job_title: Area DIrector/Area Administrative in Spokane, WA
pros: Strong emphasis on building relationships as the foundation of all that is done throughout the organization encourages lifelong friendships. Areas are given a lot of freedom to creatively find ways to work with the community and school where they are active.
cons: At times, the position of Area Director can feel isolated; especially if you are in a small town. The freedom to adapt that is given to Areas can be tough to work with when you are new to the organization and looking for more specific guidance on how to approach the community and school. Fundraising the Area budget can be difficult depending on the area where you working.

review_title: Amazing group, needs a little more organization
pros: The community is like no other. You will build life-time relationships in this organization. The work is meaningful, you are tangibly making a difference in teens lives. Also, it's fun!!
cons: It's easy to burn-out because the "work-load" is never-ending. You have to be good at setting boundaries or it takes up your entire life. Also, you have to fundraise a lot.

review_title: Young Life is the best avenue for relationally bringing the Gospel to disinterested adolescents.
pros:
Front - lines mission
Organization mission driven for 60 years
Training is great. All field staff are put in a position to use and develop executive level skills from day one.
Benefits are great.
Famiy is valued.
My job has purpose.
cons: If do not have a good regional director this job can be difficult.

pros: Community is huge for property staff. I was lucky enough to have a very solid community at the property I was a part of. People are really there in order to see a change in high schoolers lives. No one is in it for the pay.
cons: Can be very political. Some camping properties have management in place that lacks professionalism or management skills. Overall, upper management seems to be out of touch with what the mission is doing. Compensation is minimal.

pros: Strong mission, good program, tremendous people in the field staff and volunteer core.  Hard work, but very meaningful and fun when things are running well (can be very stressful when they are not, however).
cons: Regional/National leadership seemed more interested in Regional/National objectives, rather than supporting field staff.  Service charge fee to Region/National was high compared to the value of support received.  Weak to no support to local chapter as it relates to succession planning when local staff transition away.  Not much by way of longer-term career path or vision for development/advancement if you are on staff more than 10 years.

pros: Working for Young Life provides employees an opportunity to make a difference in the lives of kids, and also an opportunity to be mentored and invested in by older employees.
cons: Working for Young Life is the hardest job that you can have. It will be physically, mentally, emotionally and spiritually taxing. The pay is not great, but such is often the case with non-profits and ministries.

pros: Leading is a very fulfilling experience with eternal relevance.  It's a tremendously fun job quite often.  There is lots of room to be creative!  It is tremendously exciting seeing high school students meet or grow closer to Christ & getting to walk with them in their pursuit of Him.
cons: COntact work can be very time-consuming.  Kids can be some times frustrating, and certainly emotionally trying at times.

pros: I think Young Life is hands down the best outreach organization that genuinely goes after kids for the sake of helping them. Volunteers and staff are surrounded by schools and community that want to help make a difference in the lives of young people.
cons: Sometimes the term faith based outreach organization gets a bad rep. Some people are less open to initial conversations when they hear that we tell kids about Jesus.

review_title: The higher up you go, the less time you spend doing what you love.
pros: Working with adolescents is very fulfilling, especially in a religious context.
cons: Upper management is not listening to their staff's concerns, very poor retention.

job_title: Staff Associate III in Westfield, NJ
pros: Great area to do ministry and reach kids/families. Good benefits. Amazing location. Young Life's resources for staff are high-par. Kids in the area are fantastic!
cons: Little to no support from committee. Constant neglect from Regional Director and regional trainers. Area is in deficit; information to which was intentionally withheld during the interview process. Reduced salary without prior notice. Ministry is run like a business. Little-to-no effective assistance from regional management, while expectation/demands for staff are both high and unrealistic.

review_title: younglife isn't what it used to be.
pros: I have freedom of job scheduling.
cons: too much of a corporate atmosphere.  this is supposed to be a ministry.

pros: The people in the organization are incredible. Have a sense of making a difference in the world.
cons: Base salaries without a COLA are not competitive. The need to constantly raise money and grown in an organization that is supposed to be service orientated around helping the person right in front of you.

pros: It's ministry, and it can be very rewarding. Benefits are good. Lots of good people to work with.
cons: Can be very political. Some camping properties have management in place that lacks professionalism or management skills. Overall, upper management seems to be out of touch with what the mission is doing. Compensation is minimal. Results are prioritized above employee health.

pros: You get to hangout with people, take spontaneous trips, mentor kids, tell people about Jesus, and get paid for it. AMAZING BENEFITS. (Insurance, financial, etc)
cons: It is a nonstop job and people will always be contacting you whether it's someone you work with, or a boss or a friend or a kid you mentor or a committee mermen or donor....you can feel like you're not getting alone time or able to relax sometimes because people are always asking to hangout with them or do something for them.

review_title: not what it seems to be.
pros: great ministry, relationships built. Camping is a wonderful experience that transforms lives. YoungLife has some exceptional employees that are caring and hard working. I absolutely love the work being done but disappointed in the leadership for staff.
cons: poor organizational leadership,lack of professional knowledge, extremely poor communication for staff. Staff retention rates are very disturbing, do your research. Lots of unchristian situations occur within the organization.  Not many staff develop a career out of Younglife, there is a reason for it.

pros: Love Young Life and its mission.  The people I've met are great, and I've loved my experience with Young Life.  I've learned a lot about leading people towards Christ, and what it means to live and walk with Christ in my daily life.  The mentorship I've received in terms of learning how to do ministry and relationally walk and build up people has been outstanding.
cons: Fundraising is difficult unless you know someone who is willing to help support you.

job_title: Outreach Coordinator in San Francisco, CA
pros: Mission of Young Life is excellent. Lots of mentorship and support for volunteers. The Young Life culture is positive and enjoyable. Opportunities to participate in trips such as Surf Trips, Summer Camps, and Winter Camps with the youth.
cons: Full-time positions are hard to come by since the hiring process for an actual Area Director position are rigorous, not to mention the candidate must fundraise their own salary.

job_title: Student Staff Associate in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Young Life extends its mission over into how they treat their employees--everything is very relational and personal.  I loved getting to go to our area and regional meetings because it always just felt like catching up with friends and getting to work along side of them!
cons: It is a challenge to raise your own pay--and I was only part-time!  It's a neat experience to trust in the Lord with your finances, though, so I can't say it is a total con.

pros: Good salary and incredible insurance benefits for ministry position. Community you work in ideally is life giving, flexible schedule.
cons: Fundraise every cent of salary, benefits and operating budget. Varies by location but less then ideal support. No one gets promoted based on results, just favoritism and if you haven't rocked the boat at all.

pros: What a wonderful mission.  Nothing more rewarding than bringing kids to Christ.  Beautiful camps to send our kids to.  Supportive and loving community.  It's fun... Young Life is all about fun and enjoying life.
cons: Unrealistic expectations for very low pay.

pros: Great Christian environment! Great people; great friends! I miss Young Life! Great to work for a ministry that works to bring teen's into relationship with Jesus!
cons: Their Service Center is not in Pennsylvania! Although I loved my job there I was tied to the desk; I like to be up and moving more.

review_title: Young Life is much more than a job - it's a family, community and amazing mission to be a part of!"
pros:
Young Life's mission to share Jesus with students and help them walk and grow in their faith.
Community of amazingly fun, talented and creative staff and volunteers.
cons: You won't want to work anywhere else ever.

pros: Great community workplace with a lot of flexibility to try out different positions. Top of the line benefits, which makes up for the lack of pay.
cons: You dont' get paid too much. And you have to deal, from time to time, with outrageous requests. Sometimes you're isolated because you work in rural areas.

pros: While serving as a volunteer provides no compensation, the excitement and joy of working with kids and other leaders is rewarding enough. My job is basically to be a friend. Friendships are awesome. It's how you build great memories.
cons: No pay as a volunteer (but that's not why we work here anyway). As far as a résumé goes, it's not the most useful "experience".

pros: I enjoyed being a positive role model for teens
cons: Young Life and its staff create a culture of secrecy.  Leaders and staff are not allowed to disclose the organization's policies and they often fear questioning the policies or even discussing them.  Leaders are encouraged to use deceptive methods to attract vulnerable teens and get them involved.  Area Directors and staff lie to their communities and donors about what they are doing, highly exaggerating in order to create the appearance of being more effective than they really are so that donors will see value and donate more.

review_title: Loved my time, the people make this job worthwhile.
pros: Great culture of fun, adventure, humor. Love working with these people...the upper management is humorous and really seem to care about lower level people but don't have the time to invest in them.
cons: Pay-Came on staff and make $1650/mo (pre tax) in the first two years. Sometimes ministry has no boundaries (work at nights/weekends), and it's hard if you're coming in to a new area.

review_title: Passionate organization that strives to be excellent in all it does
pros: Excellent youth ministry training, amazing camps, and the opportunity to make a lasting impact on a community.  Young Life takes care of their employees and sets them up to be successful.
cons: Raising money for the area can be a difficult process if the area is new or in a transition.  Often times really talented people have to leave staff because the area can no longer afford to pay them.

pros: The people.  It is very hard to find a better group of people to work with.  Also the benefits are awesome.  What can be better than a all staff conference in Florida every four years.
cons: In my opinion there may not be a "clear" development plan for property staff.

job_title: Area Director in Colorado Springs, CO
pros: There is a lot of autonomy, and freedom to do what works, depending on where you are on staff.
cons: Leadership at the top is extremely regressive, numbers-focused, and narrow.  Opportunities for advancement are basically non-existent, unless you want to be a regional director (which is entirely administrative, no real hands-on work).  Some regions have terrible leadership and everyone suffers.

pros: Being a YL leader is so much fun and very rewarding! It's amazing to teach others about Jesus! The people you meet in this position are amazing.
cons: The only con I would say is that it can be very time-consuming, especially if you do not set strict time limits and manage your time well. It can consume your life.

pros: It's a great company that's centered around getting kids to Christ! It's about having fun and not boring high school students with the gospel. If you never want to grow up, then this is that organization for you. Fun 24/7.
cons: You can easily be discouraged when you are not seeing the results of your hard work. But you must trust that The Lord will use your labors even if you can't see them instantly.

pros:
Intentional Mentorship
Intensive leadership training
Loving community of coworkers
Perfect balance of support and challenge 
Beautiful location on the Princess Louisa Inlet
Housing and Food free
cons: Not many cons, the main thing is that it is a two year commitment and a volunteer position so you must time it right in order to work for Beyond.

review_title: The best experience of my life!
pros: Worked with amazing people. Formed lifetime relationships with leaders and students.  The most rewarding work I have ever done.  Really just enjoy every minute of it and never wanted it to end.  It was more like play than work.  I was able to meet a lot of valuable contacts throughout my time there.
cons: There are no cons about working here.

pros:
Great group of staff who work together well. 
Good training programs for new staff.
Excellence in many areas of ministry.
Great reputation.
cons:
Incredible demand on time schedule and constant push towards growth even when it does not always benefit the area. 
If the area has poor funding, employees can go without pay for considerable periods.

pros: The ability to use your story of redemption in earning the right to be heard in the lives of kids. Flexible schedule.
cons: Work/Life balance. Hard to figure out what to turn off when life is Young Life. Low pay.

pros: Young Life is unrivaled in its high calling and impact. The community you get from being a part of this organization is incredible!
cons: This is a very high burnout job. If you aren't in it for the long run, it will be a very difficult job to have.

review_title: The best organization I have had the opportunity to be a part of.
pros: You will be surrounded by the most love and authenticity imaginable by being a part of Young Life. You will be met where you are, grown, challenged, and encouraged more than ever thought possible.
cons: The only con I can think of is the emotional investment is overwhelming, but in reality, that is one of the greatest gifts of this ministry.

pros: thr community of younglife is amazing.  Their mission is valuable.  Work that makes a difference.
cons: Can be emotionally taxing.  The pay isn't the greatest but kingdom work pays in other ways.   Work that lives with you, can't really leave it at the office at 5pm.

pros: You get to interact with people on a daily basis and get to create you're own schedule essentially. Very hard job but really good.
cons: You have to work a lot of nights which can be really hard, especially with a family. Fundraising your salary isn't too fun either.

pros: Very interactive with students, volunteers, and employees alike. Very upbeat and positive environment. Goal oriented company that is heavy of prayer and God's guidance in every decision.
cons: Very fast paced job working in the office. Many hours are spent alone as you complete tasks. You must be very self- disciplined and invested spiritually and emotionally to be able to complete all of the inner- office tasks for very little pay.

pros: Young life has an awesome focused mission and is a great place to work.  The work is rewarding and diverse.  Had great trainers who care about you as a person not just your work.
cons: Biggest con is you can feel like an island sometimes especially if you are starting an area.  If you have a strong entrepreneurial spirit this should not be a problem.

review_title: An organization that is making a difference
pros: I had the opportunity to participate in meaningful work alongside supportive co-workers who made me feel valued, and I went home every day knowing that I was making a difference in the lives of teenagers.
cons: Young Life is an international organization that is run like a grassroots organization locally, so it is lacking certain structures and employee support that a for-profit is not.

pros: They strive for excellence, and expect that from new employees as well. Young Life gives you great training, incredible benefits, and valuable experience.
cons: Some of the processes are unprofessional, or come across as lazy. The interview process and job placement/start-up process, for instance, takes entirely too long. You're often left waiting for months without hearing any update. Something they constantly try to improve on, however.

review_title: Know what you are getting into
pros:
Ministry work sharing the Gospel is always great!
Work with kids
Training once you become full-time
Benefits are awesome compared to other companies
cons:
You have to be very entrepreneurial to succeed
You are left to yourself without day-to-day support
Lack of focus on minority and under-resourced communities
Unfulfilled promise of full-time employment
Work-life balance expectations are out of whack

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: The mission, the fellow staff, the benefits (especially health). But also the "perks" of having meetings at Young Life camps in some of the most beautiful places not only in the U.S. but on Earth.
cons: Strong corporate culture makes it difficult to "break in" unless you have a background or history with the organization. Very few "cons" with Young Life. Awesome place to work.

pros: Love working with executives, parents, and community members to ensure a better future for student in these towns. Community and Schools work together to establish the best for students
cons: Consuming job that is hard to separate from your life. It is a job where you are constantly on the clock since you are dealing with students and their struggles they go through

pros: Working on Student Staff was the most I learned about ministry, fundraising, and team work. I am thankful for those that were a shepherd to me and were able to encourage me to pursue God's calling for me into ministry!
cons: I really didn't have any! Fundraising definitely takes prayer and trust in the Lord's provision- but that is in no way a con!

review_title: Great Place to Be A Part or Something Big
pros: If you are called to youth ministry, this is a great place to live out your calling.  Great support and training.  Great community.  Dedicated and available leadership.
cons: You are responsible for raising almost your entire support - but that is not bad.  Just know that raising ministry funds is part of the job.

review_title: Young Life is an incredible organization to work for until you have kids.
pros: Flexible schedule, incredible benefits, wonderful community.
cons: Terrible compensation, lack of organizational structure, not much room for growth.

review_title: Young Life -- You were made for this
pros: Supportive work culture, flexible schedule, meaningful work, great coworkers, It is fun to work here-great if you are a relational people person.
cons: Fundraising a salary can be stressful, sometime a difficult to find a good work/life balance, It can be hard to afford to support a family on an Area DIrector's salary in many parts of the country

pros: Young Life staff is not for the faint of heart, but it is for those who want to grow in their faith and their leadership ability.
cons: Because of the nature of vocational ministry, maintaining a work-life balance can be difficult. While it is not the organization's fault, I would recommend strongly considering your ability to set boundaries before pursuing this job.

pros:
- Work is very rewarding
- Friendly people to work with
- Health care benefits are fantastic
cons:
- top down system causes decisions to take forever
- very little individual freedom, even though they tell you that you have oversight of your area

pros: I loved working with people that shared the same passion for students as I do. Young Life is an incredible ministry with an incredible mission.
cons: Young Life is a wonderful ministry that changes the lives of hundred of thousands of students each and every year however getting paid to do it in a way took some joy out of doing it.

pros: Encouraging environment with high potential of personal growth. Also, many fun opportunities and long lasting friendships. Opportunities to make a lasting impact in people's lives.
cons: This is a high energy, up tempo environment, sometimes employees can be over looked by upper management. This can be a very tiring job as well.

pros: Working for Young Life, guaranteed you're doing work that is changing lives, which not everybody gets to do in their life. Your personal growth is highly important to all your supervisors.
cons: It can at times be difficult to determine what is the next best step in program development, but that can easily be determined with supervisors and peers.

review_title: Amazing opportunity to grow personally and develop skills/relationships.
pros: There aren't many jobs where your first part of business is your personal health which includes spending time with Christ. The community is wonderful. The work is rewarding. Wonderful ministry to work with.
cons: Can be a never ending job. Must learn to balance work and life or what either truly is.

pros: Being challenged, great community, biblical counseling and teaching, fundraising teaching, leadership opportunities, learning to be selfless
cons: not enough time for full time school, student staff and to work on the side since it doesn't pay enough

review_title: Great job if you can balance work and life
pros: Some of the most thrilling experiences and long-lasting relationships have come from working here.
cons: Discern if your direct supervisor exhibits a good balance between work and life. If unchecked, this job could consume you.

pros: One of the most intentional and caring careers you can take in the world. Strategic thinkers, self-starters, and relational spirits are successful.
cons: Very easy to overwork, and to be a lone ranger in the field.

pros: I love being able to go talk to my boss about anything. He cares about me, my walk with God, and my work ethic. I love how I can do my job as I live my day to day life.
cons: Not an 9-5 job... This is a full-time, 24/7 job.

pros: Great people and organization to work for. Highly recommend it, they set you up well to work in ministry and with kids.
cons:
Low pay and low structure. Easy to get lost if you don't have entrepreneurial spirit.
No balance between your work life and personal life.

pros: It is a relational ministry and they maintain that in the office as well. Great benefits, and staff care about people before work.
cons: Still have politics like you do anywhere, not the best at developing people in their careers, but there is a concentrated effort to change this.

review_title: For Christ and community, not Glory
pros:
Volunteer nature makes it extremely likely that you work with selfless, awesome people. Similarly, you work with kids and play lots of games, so your peers tend to be fun. 
Very rewarding to help kids and further the YL mission.
cons: Big commitment, requires courage/awkward moments

pros: Great leadership. Wonderful people to be around. Good training and support. Wonderful outreach ministry to youth. They know how to earn the right to be heard.
cons: Not very many cons really. You have to raise your own support which is a lot of work but strengths your faith.

pros: A genuine organization that cares about its employees from the top-down. The culture, people, and constant positive support is amazing.
cons: Pay is not great but that's to be expected. Not a job you do for the money. The Experience and maturity growth was worth more to me.

pros: Young Life is an amazing organization to be a part of. As a volunteer leader I was given opportunities and skills that have pushed me to succeed in both ministry and my career.
cons: Young Life is a very tie consuming career and/or volunteer position. Time management is key!

pros: Lots of support from staff around you, strong core values of reaching kids and overall very fun place.
cons: You primarily work remotely from an area office or your home. Thus you don't have a lot of office type interaction on a day to day basis.

review_title: Too Big - Has gotten away from its intended mission
pros: Lots of freedom, rewarding, friends for life
cons: lonely job, if you have a terrible area director, might as well quit right now. Everything revolves around them. Can never truly turn off, lots of travel

pros: Young Life offers great medical/dental benefits as well as a solid retirement/pension program. The leadership of the org is aligned in the mission/vision of the org.
cons: Non-medical benefits are slightly behind the times for an org this size. At times, departments experience the pressures of being under-resourced.

review_title: You work with a lot of volunteers
pros: Small benefits package for part-time employees. Can be very flexible depending on your area.
cons: Each area within the world wide organization is ran differently. There are few paid employees at the area level so you find yourself relying on inconsistent volunteers.

review_title: Not for everyone. One of the most rewarding experiences.
pros: Management and leadership are the loneliest positions. YL creates environments that are established on relationships and dedication. Networking experiences are unmatched.
cons: Salary is through donations which becomes very humbling.

pros: Wonderful culture, great mission - there are too many pros to name.
cons: Not any major cons to name. Every workplace has some cons but none of the ones I encountered at YL stick in my memory.

pros: Flexibility of schedule and hours. Could do something different each day. The work is mission minded -purposeful. Great benefits.
cons: Work 2-3 nights a week. Not very structured - had to create own structure. Could be paid more.

pros: The ability to serve Christ and Military Families
cons: Overhead cost from contract money. Having to fund raise but rules about fundraising within the community (Rules have changed since I worked in my location).

review_title: Perfect for a full time student
pros: Understanding coworkers who care to see you strive with the ministry, but also care to see you strive in your everyday life
cons: None, really.  Young Life allowed me to do what I love and be active in my community

pros: The best benefits on the market, fun atmosphere and rewarding to work with the people you do.
cons: The schedule was really tough, always changing with early mornings and late nights. Sometimes hard to separate work from personal life.

review_title: Global Cities Fellow in Hong Kong
job_title: Global Cities Fellow in Hong Kong
pros: Relationships, relationships, relationships. Working at Young Life builds lifelong friendships - with your team, with leaders, and with kids - that have a very real impact.
cons: Lots of freedom could be problematic for those who enjoy more structured schedules.

pros: Great community and environment. Awesome values and a great organization to be a part of. Wouldn't recommend anything higher.
cons: Very time consuming, but if you are supposed to be doing this, that shouldn't be a problem!

pros: Humor, Fun, Freedom, Leadership Opportunities, Impact
cons: Fundraising, Stress, Overworking, Challenging, Feeling of failure often

pros: Meaningful and impactful mission. Leadership cares for their employees.
cons: The nature of the ministry can lead to burnout, but it's a great organization!

pros: Leadership and team work, they train you in different aspects of leadership, recruit volunteers, disciple current volunteers.
cons: Not really any lows, just that sometimes you travel out of state and being a part time is not really an advantege.

pros: Truly seeks to be an impact on high school kids who would normally never feel comfortable setting foot into a church and building positive and gospel centered relationships with them.
cons: It can vary in leadership from district to district

Rewarding beyond comprehension
Flexible

cons: At times felt isolated from other staff members.

pros: YL is a great organization. It is a really intentional ministry that focuses on reaching lost kids.
cons: Its really hard work. You have to fundraise and work long hours and weeks. You also don't get paid super well.

pros: Very nice people to work with, it was the perfect winter job while I was in high school.
cons: I felt that I was not being used to my full potential or being taught everything.

pros: Working with families and kids.
